author: Jon Swartz
title: Palo Alto Networks Issues AI Red Alert
text:
SANTA CLARA, Calif. — With great promise comes potential peril. And while artificial intelligence (AI) is looked upon as a panacea for enterprises, it also poses an existential security threat.
“We stand at the intersection of human ingenuity and technological innovation, where the game of cybersecurity has evolved into a high-stakes match,” Nir Zuk , founder and chief technology officer at Palo Alto Networks Inc., said at the company’s 2025 Cybersecurity and AI Predictions event here late Thursday.
As AI becomes the driving force in security operations centers (SOC), with human analysts playing a crucial but secondary role, SOCs will increasingly rely on AI-driven processes to automate tasks such as vulnerability scanning and threat detection while reserving advanced analytics and response strategies for human experts, according to the annual threat assessment.
Secure operations are increasingly essential in the age of AI hype because more than 40% of business and technology leaders admit to lacking a full understanding of cyber-risks associated with generative AI, according to PwC’s 2024 Global Digital Trust Insights survey.
The rising concern over data breaches necessitates tighter control over corporate resources, Palo Alto Networks’ report cautions. Consumer web browsers are inherently insecure, with 95% of organizations reporting security incidents originating from the browser across all devices, underscoring the lack of necessary security measures to protect organizations and their employees, no matter where they work.
The AI arms race is a “double-edged sword” that brings a new attack surface that can expose greater sensitive information more quickly, Sam Rubin, vice president and global head of operations, Unit 42, at Palo Alto Networks, said in an interview. The good news, he added, is that AI can be used for security enhancements and as an asymmetrical defense.
Companies face a 2025 cybersecurity landscape, according to Palo Alto Networks, which offered several predictions. Among them:
Cybersecurity will shift toward a unified data platform. Platforms will encompass everything from code development, cloud environments and SOCs. Current fragmented systems, burdened with isolated workflows and manual processes, cannot match the speed and sophistication of modern cyberthreats.
Large incumbent organizations with vast data stores will take the lead in AI-driven innovation, gaining a powerful advantage over new entrants. Companies like Palo Alto Networks, which processes seven petabytes of data daily across multiple platforms and serves 85,000 customers, are positioned to dominate in a data-centric AI landscape, the company claimed. AI’s success hinges on data quality and volume, with nearly 90% of model performance relying on these elements.
Energy is a concern, especially in cybersecurity. A surge in AI workloads has triggered a corresponding increase in data centers worldwide, with enterprise cloud storage projected to more than double to $128 billion by 2028, according to Omdia research. This growth brings a significant rise in electricity consumption, with Big Tech’s energy demands escalating. In response, the industry will need to adopt energy-conscious strategies that include platformization, energy-efficient AI models, and quantum-based AI models, said Palo Alto Networks.

author: Anujj Trehaan
title: Unveiling Osa Peninsula's waterfalls and petroglyphs
text:
Summarize Simplifying... In short Embark on an adventure through the Osa Peninsula's lush rainforests, home to hidden waterfalls and ancient petroglyphs. This wildlife haven offers stunning views, encounters with local fauna, and a glimpse into the region's history and conservation efforts. Don't forget your hiking shoes, binoculars, and a thirst for discovery! Was a long read? Making it simpler... Next Article Next Article Calling all travel freaks
Unveiling Osa Peninsula's waterfalls and petroglyphs By Anujj Trehaan Oct 04, 2024 09:56 am What's the story The Osa Peninsula in Costa Rica is a treasure trove of natural beauty and ancient history. This remote corner of the world is home to cascading waterfalls, dense rainforests, and mysterious petroglyphs carved by ancient inhabitants. It's a place where adventure meets history, offering visitors a unique opportunity to explore untouched landscapes and delve into the rich cultural heritage of Costa Rica.
Waterfall trek Hike to hidden waterfalls Embark on a journey through the Osa Peninsula's lush rainforests to find hidden waterfalls. These natural wonders, nestled in dense jungle, require hiking to reach. Trails offer stunning views and encounters with local wildlife. At the waterfalls, visitors can swim in the crystal-clear pools. It's advised to wear comfortable hiking shoes and bring enough water for the trek.
Petroglyph discovery Explore ancient petroglyphs The Osa Peninsula is renowned not just for its natural beauty but also for historical significance. Ancient petroglyphs, carved by Indigenous people thousands of years ago, are scattered across this region. Hiring a local guide can offer insights into the meanings and significance of these carvings, providing a glimpse into the ancient lives of the area's original inhabitants.
Wildlife watching Experience local wildlife The Osa Peninsula is a haven for wildlife enthusiasts, boasting monkeys, toucans, and sloths. For optimal wildlife watching, aim for early morning or late afternoon visits. It's essential to bring binoculars and a camera for these encounters. Always maintain a respectful distance from the animals and strictly adhere to guidelines to ensure their protection. This approach safeguards both the wildlife and your experience.
Eco-tourism Conservation efforts tour Discover the Osa Peninsula's conservation efforts by visiting its many eco-friendly projects or reserves. These tours offer insights into how local communities collaborate to preserve their natural environment, while also promoting sustainable tourism practices. It's a chance not only to witness conservation in action but also to understand how each visitor contributes to protecting this incredible ecosystem for future generations.

author: @nbc6
title: Flood Advisory issued for Broward County as heavy rain, potential for severe weather continues – NBC 6 South Florida
text: A Flood Advisory has been issued Friday in Broward County, according to the National Weather Service. The advisory lasts until 4:30 p.m. and covers Fort Lauderdale, Pembroke Pines, Hollywood, Miramar, Davie, and more. In preparation for a [busy weekend in South Florida](https://www.nbcmiami.com/news/local/miami-open-tennis-2024/3252784/) with different events taking place in our cities, it looks like we’ll be in the crosshairs for [active weather.](https://www.nbcmiami.com/news/local/heavy-rain-expected-during-busy-weekend-in-south-florida-this-is-what-to-expect/3263801/) Get South Florida local news, weather forecasts and entertainment stories to your inbox. [Sign up for NBC South Florida newsletters.] A warm front is coming our way. An area of low pressure is working across the northern Gulf of Mexico and pushing a warm front across our area on Friday. This will spread tropical air across South Florida, with the heaviest rain and best chance for thunderstorms by the second half of the day. With the low-pressure center, there is a chance for isolated tornadoes, strong wind, and flooding. Heavy rain will move in midday, but the most intense storms are expected to move in late Friday evening. A Flood Watch is in effect through Saturday for 2-4 inches of rainfall and 6+ inches locally. A Wind Advisory is also in effect until 8 p.m. Saturday with sustained winds expected at 20-25 mph with gusts up to or over 40 mph. THIS WEEKEND IN SOUTH FLORIDA This is important to have in mind [if you’re planning to attend an event such as Ultra](https://www.nbcmiami.com/news/local/miami-music-week-2024-see-the-events-leading-up-to-ultras-grand-finale/3262321/), which is taking place at Bayfront Park in Downtown Miami — an area that is not strange to flooding. We will stay locked into this unstable air mass into Saturday, with periods of heavy rain throughout the day. By the end of the day, things will look to clear out and we improve by the second half of the weekend. It's still early, so stay with NBC6 and the [First Alert Weather](https://www.nbcmiami.com/weather/nbc-6-todays-forecast-first-alert-weather-south-florida/1883450/) Team as we continue to analyze the data and fine-tune the forecast.

author: Lynn Kolongei
title: Ruto allies claim Gachagua isolating Mt Kenya
text: President William Ruto’s allies in Mt Kenya have accused Deputy President Rigathi Gachagua of isolating central Kenya. The Kenya Kwanza leaders, led by Laikipia East MP Mwangi Kiunjuri claimed that [Gachagua is plotting](https://www.standardmedia.co.ke/article/2001501418/stop-politicking-and-push-farmers-interests-gachagua-tells-leaders?utm_cmp_rs=amp-next-page) to isolate Mt Kenya communities from the rest of the country ahead of the 2027 General Election. Speaking in Eldoret, Kiunjuri alleged that there was a scheme by the DP and a section of politicians to cause a rift in the Kenya Kwanza government to weaken the President's political influence in the region. The leaders who held a meeting with members of the Kikuyu community from the North Rift region at a hotel in Kapseret, Uasin Gishu county said they will not sit and watch as the Gachagua attempts to pit the Mt Kenya community against the rest of the country. Kiunjuri insisted that the country had been united through the broad-based government and Central should not be isolated. “Those in Kenya Kwanza should not be the ones giving the President a hard time. Even if you are a shareholder, hold your horses knowing that the shares have been divided equitably. I will write a text message to Rigathi informing him that people in the Rift Valley want peace; they do not want wrangles in the government. If a woman is married, she should be satisfied with her husband,” he said. Kiunjuri who is The Service Party leader has vowed to ensure Mt Kenya remains steadfast in the ruling Kenya Kwanza Alliance. “The in-fights in the Kenya Kwanza divide are not helpful at all. We fight while others are taking advantage of our differences. If a husband and wife are fighting, there will be no stability in their home, if a community is in constant fights, passersby will draw in, steal from them and they will know no peace,” he said. The leaders accused Gachagua of rocking the government from within instead of helping the president unite Kenyans from across the political divide. “We are going to oppose attempts by the DP to try and isolate members of the [Mt Kenya region](https://www.standardmedia.co.ke/business/politics/article/2001501136/gachagua-i-have-grown-thick-skin-to-survive-politics?utm_cmp_rs=amp-next-page) from the rest of Kenyans for his own political gain. While the country is united through the broad-based government, why should we be the ones anticipating disunity?” Posed Kiunjuri. The meeting that was hosted by UDA Nominated MP Joseph Wainaina, was attended by MPs Duncan Mathenge (Nyeri Central), John Kiarie (Dagoretti), James Githua (Kabete) and John Kiragu (Limuru). Kiunjuri said that they will pick a leader from Gema to champion their unity. He revealed that the Eldoret meeting was just one of the forums they have lined up across the country to preach peace and undo the political damage to the Mt Kenya community that has settled and is doing business in other counties. “The DP should not concentrate his politics in Mt Kenya because we have members of our community living across the 47 counties of the country. He (Gachagua) should instead focus on helping the President to deliver on his pre-election pledge to Kenyans,” said Kiunjuri. Dagoretti MP reiterated Mt Kenya leaders commitment to support President Ruto’s transformation agenda to enable all regions to enjoy the fruits of the Kenya Kwanza government. “Let us support the broad-based government lest we be locked out as a community. We have to unite with other Kenyans because we cannot isolate ourselves. We cannot act as if we are an island. We need others and we will continue supporting President Ruto because he is a great leader, he only needs time,” he said. Wainaina claimed that Gachagua was endangering his political career by championing the interests of only one region. “It hurts to see the DP championing the interests of one region yet he holds a public office where he should be helping the President to ensure every part of the country gets a share of the national cake,” he said. The nominated MP urged the Mt Kenya community to coexist peacefully with others. “In as much as we have the numbers from Mt Kenya region, our people are spread out in all counties, and in these counties, they are the minority. What happens if we isolate ourselves instead of embracing other communities?” Wainana posed.

author: Wes
title: The Surprising Firework That Sends the Most People to the ER In Texas - NewsBreak
text:
Texas
The Surprising Firework That Sends the Most People to the ER In Texas
By Wes,
3 hours agoI certainly don't want to put a damper on your 4th of July activities—I just want to give you a heads-up that some things aren't as harmless as they seem. You’ll get no preaching about fireworks from me. I’ve probably done every bad thing you can do with fireworks, so I don’t have much room to talk. And I’m not here to lecture you about stuff you’d rather ignore. Let's just protect Texas kids.

author: Redaccción Judicial
title: Asesinaron a dos hombres y les dejaron un cartel "por ratas"
text:
Las víctimas presentaban múltiples heridas causadas por arma de fuego. Aun no han sido identificadas.
Las autoridades del municipio de Guarne, en el Oriente antioqueño, investigan el asesinato de dos hombres cuyos cuerpos fueron encontrados en la vereda Guamito, sector La Antena, una zona rural ubicada a unos 25 minutos del casco urbano. El hallazgo se produjo este martes 8 de abril, alrededor de las 3:30 p. m.
Según información recopilada en el lugar de los hechos, las víctimas presentaban múltiples heridas causadas por arma de fuego. Aunque aún no han sido identificadas, una de las hipótesis que manejan los investigadores es que los hombres, que se movilizaban en una motocicleta, habrían sido seguidos por otros dos sujetos en moto, quienes les dispararon minutos después de una aparente persecución. Le puede interesar: Hirió a un hombre a balazos en medio de una discusión: irá 4 años a la cárcel
Llamó la atención de los investigadores un letrero encontrado junto a los cuerpos con la frase “por ratas”, el cual fue recogido como posible elemento clave dentro del proceso investigativo.
Desde la Alcaldía de Guarne lamentamos el hecho violento ocurrido hoy en la vereda Guamito, sector La Antena. Dos hombres en moto, perseguidos desde otro municipio, fueron ultimados en nuestra jurisdicción. Autoridades ya investigan a los responsables.
— Alcaldía Guarne (@AlcaldiaGuarne)[April 8, 2025]
La secretaria de Gobierno de Guarne, Elisaria Torres Roldán, confirmó que la Policía Nacional y el Cuerpo Técnico de Investigación (CTI) lideran las diligencias judiciales para esclarecer este hecho: “La Policía Nacional y el CTI dirigen la investigación por el doble homicidio ocurrido este martes 8 de abril, en horas de la tarde, en zona rural de la localidad”, afirmó.
Torres Roldán también señaló que los dos hombres ultimados eran perseguidos desde el municipio de San Vicente Ferrer y fueron interceptados finalmente en jurisdicción de Guarne. Hasta el momento no ha sido localizada la motocicleta en la que se transportaban las víctimas.
Por su parte, la Alcaldía de Guarne se pronunció a través de un comunicado oficial en el que lamentó lo ocurrido: “Desde la Alcaldía de Guarne lamentamos el hecho violento ocurrido hoy en la vereda Guamito, sector La Antena. Dos hombres en moto, perseguidos desde otro municipio, fueron ultimados en nuestra jurisdicción. Autoridades ya investigan a los responsables”.
— Hora13 Noticias (@hora13noticias)
[#Hora13Noticias]Daniel Torres Gutiérrez está en Medicina Legal de Medellín[https://t.co/OuNYEJV0cI][April 9, 2025]

author: UK & international sports
title: Arsenal denied a return to Premier League summit as they are beaten by West Ham
text:
Arsenal denied a return to Premier League summit as they are beaten by West Ham
The Gunners went down 2-0 at home
Arsenal missed the chance to return to the top of the Premier League as they slipped to a disappointing defeat to West Ham amid more VAR controversy.
The Gunners needed victory to replace Liverpool at the summit but lost 2-0 by the Hammers on a night where David Moyes finally landed a victory at the Emirates Stadium.
His West Ham side lost Kurt Zouma ahead of the game and Lucas Paqueta after just over half an hour but hit the front through Tomas Soucek’s strike, awarded after VAR could not determine whether the whole ball had gone out of play in the build-up.
A second-half header from former Arsenal defender Konstantinos Mavropanos secured the points and things could have been even better for the visitors had Said Benrahma not seen a last-gasp penalty saved by David Raya.
Moyes had failed to secure victory in his previous 72 Premier League away games at Arsenal, Chelsea, Liverpool or Manchester United, so this was a long time coming for the Scot.
Arsenal laboured when they needed to continue their recent winning run in London derbies to go back to the top of the table.
Instead, only captain Martin Odegaard could hold his head high on a night where their defence creaked and Gabriel Jesus was guilty of missing a couple of very good chances.
Arsenal started well, with some great touches in and around the West Ham box from Odegaard in particular.
But at the other end their defending left a lot to be desired, as Oleksandr Zinchenko and Gabriel Magalhaes failed to deal with a simple ball into the middle.
Jarrod Bowen capitalised by latching onto the miscue and teed up Soucek to finish – the goal surviving a lengthy VAR check which could not ultimately make a call on if the ball had not gone out of play before Bowen’s cutback.
Arsenal looked to respond although the goal gave West Ham something to defend, although Jesus found a way in behind with a subtle flick into Bukayo Saka, whose header was brilliantly saved by Alphonse Areola.
Paqueta had been hurt in the warm-up and lasted just over half an hour, with his fellow Brazilian Gabriel Martinelli curling an effort just wide for Arsenal as they continued in vain to find a leveller.
The hosts were getting closer, West Ham gifting possession as two passes saw Arsenal in on goal once more, this time Saka hitting the base of the post from an acute angle.
Former West Ham captain Declan Rice fired just over from 25 yards but it was another player coming back to haunt his former club who would find the back of the net soon after.
Mavropanos made just seven league starts in three years as an Arsenal player but returned to the Premier League last summer with the Hammers and headed them two goals ahead before the hour.
Jesus then headed straight at Areola before sending another fine chance well over the bar moments after Arteta introduced Eddie Nketiah and Reiss Nelson off the bench.
Areola was on hand again to keep out a Leandro Trossard effort, with Vladimir Coufal clearing a William Saliba header off the line from the resulting corner.
Rice had come off the bench during a 3-0 Carabao Cup defeat on his return to West Ham earlier in the season and endured another night to forget here as he conceded a late penalty for tripping Emerson Palmieri in the box – only for Raya to keep out substitute Benrahma’s tame spot-kick.

author: JACKSON WALKER | The National Desk
title: chevron-right
text: {p}Sunday will be a lot calmer than Saturday with some nice sunbreaks for the morning and most of the afternoon. Showers will start moving back after sunset. Highs today will hit the mid to upper 50s.{/p}{p}Showers will take over tonight making for a wet start to your Monday morning. Lows should drop to the upper 40s in most spots.{/p}{p}Monday will have frequent showers and the chance of a thundershower or two. The best chance to hear the rumble of thunder will be along the ocean beaches, areas south of Tacoma, and in the Puget Sound Convergence Zone of north King and south Snohomish Counties. Highs on Monday will make it to the mid to upper 50s once again.{/p}{p}Rain will continue on Tuesday under gray skies. Highs should drop back to a bit to the mid-50s.{/p}{p}Right now the forecast models say Wednesday should bring mostly dry weather with some sunbreaks. It will not be all that warm with daytime highs only getting to the low to mid-50s.{/p}{p}Theron Zahn{br}The KOMO 4-Cast Team{br}{/p}{p}{strong}Updated Sunday Morning{/strong}{/p}{p}The Israel Defense Forces (IDF) announced the discovery of an underground tunnel below a Gaza mosque Thursday, something it believes could be used by Hamas terrorists.{br}{/p}{p}“WATCH as IDF troops uncover a terrorist tunnel shaft hidden inside a mosque in Gaza. This is a direct threat to both Israeli and Gazan civilians,” IDF{ }{a href=\"https://twitter.com/IDF/status/1740389313802535209?s=20\" target=\"_blank\" title=\"https://twitter.com/IDF/status/1740389313802535209?s=20\"}wrote {/a}via X, the platform formerly known as Twitter. The tunnel was discovered by the military’s 55th brigade, according to the video.{/p}{p}The clip opens with an aerial shot of a partially-ruined mosque before the camera drops into the building. Weaving through rooms with shattered windows and ruined walls, the camera then shows a wide rectangular shaft opening into the floor.{/p}{p}Responding to the video was the American Jewish Committee (AJC), which believes it to be direct evidence of Hamas using civilians as \"human shields.\"{/p}{p}{sd-embed class=\"sd-embedded-media\" data-embed-file=\"1740389313802535209\" data-embed-type=\"twitter\" contenteditable=\"false\"}{/sd-embed}{/p}{p}“This shows - again - how Hamas purposely uses Palestinian civilians as human shields. #FreeGazaFromHamas,” AJC{ }{a href=\"https://twitter.com/AJCGlobal/status/1740477831514403170\" target=\"_blank\" title=\"https://twitter.com/AJCGlobal/status/1740477831514403170\"}wrote{/a}.{br}{/p}{p}Others, however, were unconvinced by the video.{/p}{p}{strong}READ MORE |{ }{a href=\"https://thenationaldesk.com/news/americas-news-now/gaza-hospital-director-confesses-to-role-as-hamas-operative-calls-terrorists-cowards-israel-palestine-middle-east-conflict-terrorism-ahmad-al-khalot-kamal-adwan-shifa#\" target=\"_blank\" title=\"https://thenationaldesk.com/news/americas-news-now/gaza-hospital-director-confesses-to-role-as-hamas-operative-calls-terrorists-cowards-israel-palestine-middle-east-conflict-terrorism-ahmad-al-khalot-kamal-adwan-shifa#\"}Gaza hospital director confesses to role as Hamas operative, calls terrorists 'cowards'{/a}{/strong}{/p}{p}“Why does the Israeli army not show the alleged tunnel?” {a href=\"https://twitter.com/IDF/status/1740389313802535209/quotes\" target=\"_blank\" title=\"https://twitter.com/IDF/status/1740389313802535209/quotes\"}asked {/a}commentator Chris Doyle. “It has before put a drone or camera down one. We just get to see an opening in the corner. This just is not evidence. (Do I think Hamas might do this? Yes quite possibly).”{/p}{p}“Again. Every f building has basements and underground bunks,” Palestinian advocate Hadi Nasrallah {a href=\"https://twitter.com/HadiNasrallah/status/1740397709620916638\" target=\"_blank\" title=\"https://twitter.com/HadiNasrallah/status/1740397709620916638\"}said{/a}. “You keep posting them without context and without showing what is inside. Or you edit a part from outside and another inside together from different tunnels and buildings. No one believes you.”{/p}{p}The IDF has been working to combat a wide network of tunnels, which it believes Hamas is using to covertly move terrorists and weapons throughout the city. The military this month {a href=\"https://thenationaldesk.com/news/nation-world/israel-flooding-hamas-terrorists-tunnels-with-seawater-report-says-gaza-strip-wall-street-journal-wsj-palestine-terrorism-middle-east-biden-netanyahu-white-house-politics-ceasefire\" target=\"_blank\" title=\"https://thenationaldesk.com/news/nation-world/israel-flooding-hamas-terrorists-tunnels-with-seawater-report-says-gaza-strip-wall-street-journal-wsj-palestine-terrorism-middle-east-biden-netanyahu-white-house-politics-ceasefire\"}built {/a}five pumps to channel seawater into tunnels with the intention of destroying them. Biden administration officials were reportedly told in a briefing the operation could take weeks to complete.{/p}{p}{strong}READ MORE |{ }{a href=\"https://thenationaldesk.com/news/americas-news-now/european-authorities-capture-four-suspected-hamas-terrorists-this-is-shameful-and-shocking-denmark-europe-danish-israel-palestine-gaza-terrorism-benjami-netanyahu#\" target=\"_blank\" title=\"https://thenationaldesk.com/news/americas-news-now/european-authorities-capture-four-suspected-hamas-terrorists-this-is-shameful-and-shocking-denmark-europe-danish-israel-palestine-gaza-terrorism-benjami-netanyahu#\"}European authorities capture four suspected Hamas terrorists: 'This is shameful and shocking'{/a}{/strong}{/p}{p}In November, IDF announced the {a href=\"https://thenationaldesk.com/news/americas-news-now/israel-defense-forces-destroy-network-of-hamas-terrorist-tunnels-pause-ceasefire-hostages-terrorist-al-shifa-rantisi-hospital-gaza-strip-war-middle-east-\" target=\"_blank\" title=\"https://thenationaldesk.com/news/americas-news-now/israel-defense-forces-destroy-network-of-hamas-terrorist-tunnels-pause-ceasefire-hostages-terrorist-al-shifa-rantisi-hospital-gaza-strip-war-middle-east-\"}destruction {/a}of a network of tunnels below the al-Shifa Hospital. The location was one of the first places to be discovered as apart of the Hamas tunnel network.{/p}{p}Sunday will be a lot calmer than Saturday with some nice sunbreaks for the morning and most of the afternoon. Showers will start moving back after sunset. Highs today will hit the mid to upper 50s.{/p}{p}Showers will take over tonight making for a wet start to your Monday morning. Lows should drop to the upper 40s in most spots.{/p}{p}Monday will have frequent showers and the chance of a thundershower or two. The best chance to hear the rumble of thunder will be along the ocean beaches, areas south of Tacoma, and in the Puget Sound Convergence Zone of north King and south Snohomish Counties. Highs on Monday will make it to the mid to upper 50s once again.{/p}{p}Rain will continue on Tuesday under gray skies. Highs should drop back to a bit to the mid-50s.{/p}{p}Right now the forecast models say Wednesday should bring mostly dry weather with some sunbreaks. It will not be all that warm with daytime highs only getting to the low to mid-50s.{/p}{p}Theron Zahn{br}The KOMO 4-Cast Team{br}{/p}{p}{strong}Updated Sunday Morning{/strong}{/p}{p}The Israel Defense Forces (IDF) announced the discovery of an underground tunnel below a Gaza mosque Thursday, something it believes could be used by Hamas terrorists.{br}{/p}{p}“WATCH as IDF troops uncover a terrorist tunnel shaft hidden inside a mosque in Gaza. This is a direct threat to both Israeli and Gazan civilians,” IDF{ }{a href=\"https://twitter.com/IDF/status/1740389313802535209?s=20\" target=\"_blank\" title=\"https://twitter.com/IDF/status/1740389313802535209?s=20\"}wrote {/a}via X, the platform formerly known as Twitter. The tunnel was discovered by the military’s 55th brigade, according to the video.{/p}{p}The clip opens with an aerial shot of a partially-ruined mosque before the camera drops into the building. Weaving through rooms with shattered windows and ruined walls, the camera then shows a wide rectangular shaft opening into the floor.{/p}{p}Responding to the video was the American Jewish Committee (AJC), which believes it to be direct evidence of Hamas using civilians as \"human shields.\"{/p}{p}{sd-embed class=\"sd-embedded-media\" data-embed-file=\"1740389313802535209\" data-embed-type=\"twitter\" contenteditable=\"false\"}{/sd-embed}{/p}{p}“This shows - again - how Hamas purposely uses Palestinian civilians as human shields. #FreeGazaFromHamas,” AJC{ }{a href=\"https://twitter.com/AJCGlobal/status/1740477831514403170\" target=\"_blank\" title=\"https://twitter.com/AJCGlobal/status/1740477831514403170\"}wrote{/a}.{br}{/p}{p}Others, however, were unconvinced by the video.{/p}{p}{strong}READ MORE |{ }{a href=\"https://thenationaldesk.com/news/americas-news-now/gaza-hospital-director-confesses-to-role-as-hamas-operative-calls-terrorists-cowards-israel-palestine-middle-east-conflict-terrorism-ahmad-al-khalot-kamal-adwan-shifa#\" target=\"_blank\" title=\"https://thenationaldesk.com/news/americas-news-now/gaza-hospital-director-confesses-to-role-as-hamas-operative-calls-terrorists-cowards-israel-palestine-middle-east-conflict-terrorism-ahmad-al-khalot-kamal-adwan-shifa#\"}Gaza hospital director confesses to role as Hamas operative, calls terrorists 'cowards'{/a}{/strong}{/p}{p}“Why does the Israeli army not show the alleged tunnel?” {a href=\"https://twitter.com/IDF/status/1740389313802535209/quotes\" target=\"_blank\" title=\"https://twitter.com/IDF/status/1740389313802535209/quotes\"}asked {/a}commentator Chris Doyle. “It has before put a drone or camera down one.
